items.content_html:
This reverts the relevant FF96 samesite changes from #10857 that were backed out by https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1750264#c9

It removes the info from release note and adds info into experimental features. Docs themselves were updated in a way such that they are independent of FF implementation of this feature, so do not need update.

Other related docs changes can be tracked in #12224
items.title: Ff96 Revert SameSite changes

items.content_html:
Fixes #12691.

auto is renamed to legacy in justify-items.

I think we could do much better at explaining the values here, and I will have a go at that, but in a follow-up, since it's unrelated to the immediate issue.
items.title: Fix issue 12691: justify-items no longer accepts auto

items.content_html:
Saying "A can be contrasted to B" may unconsciously suggest a great difference or even opposition between the two.
Saying "A is a special case of B" entails that B is a generalisation of A, suggests that the two are quite similar and invites to spot that key difference that turns an A into a B.

Summary

The proposed wording is unambiguous and more descriptive, making the content of the page more digestible.

Motivation

To make the subject easier to understand.

Supporting details

The lexical field of the word "contrast" may cause resistance to the assimilation of the subject.
Googling "contrast" we get: differ strikingly. "his friend's success contrasted with his own failure"

Related issues

  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: A small lexical change

Motivation

This page did not follow the usual structure of the assessment pages and many things were missing as well or did not make sense.

I hope these changes all fit - I've made an effort to have it set up like the other assessment pages. If I missed something, please let me know and I will adjust it.

items.content_html:
Updates https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrackCue and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrackList for new-style event pages.

Commands used:

yarn content move Web/API/TextTrackCue/onenter --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrackCue/enter_event
yarn content move Web/API/TextTrackCue/onexit Web/API/TextTrackCue/exit_event

yarn content delete Web/API/TextTrackList/onaddtrack --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrackList/addtrack_event
yarn content delete Web/API/TextTrackList/onremovetrack --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrackList/removetrack_event

No specialities here as far as I can tell. (no bubbling, no mixin)
BCD: mdn/browser-compat-data#13887
items.title: Update TextTrackCue/TextTrackList event pages

items.content_html: Used https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=docsmsft.docs-authoring-pack to cleanup the MS links to drop the locales. They do this because they redirect to the correct locale based on the user, so it's easier for i18n, because links don't need to change in the localization repos
items.title: fix: remove locales from Microsoft links

items.content_html:
Update the cuechange event pages to new event pages layout.

Here, there was no oncuechange page, but there was https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/GlobalEventHandlers/oncuechange. I removed and redirected it with:

yarn content delete Web/API/GlobalEventHandlers/oncuechange --redirect=/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrack/cuechange_event

Now there are two pages documenting cuechange:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextTrack/cuechange_event
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLTrackElement/cuechange_event (doesn't use the {{page}} macro anymore)

This is the first time I'm hitting a GlobalEventHandlers mixin case, so I appreciate if someone could double check my approach.
items.title: Update TextTrack cuechange event pages

items.title: Draft: New page: menu role

items.content_html:
Make cascading order table and described algorithm to be compliant with CSS Cascading and Inheritance Level 5 (Editor's Draft 11 January 2022).

Additionally, I believe that changing user-defined style sheet, in the example of the origin precedence, to the author style sheet would be more beneficial for the web developers as they need to know how it actually might affect their styles, rather than user-defined style sheet.
items.title: Fix Cascading Order table.

items.content_html:
Ensure that we get to user to first open the (framed) live sample in its own tab/window. Otherwise, it won’t be able to request permission to send notifications.
Fixes #2587. Fixes #12623.

Ideally, the code for this entire example should be rewritten — along with large parts of the article. But the scope of this PR isn’t to rewrite the entire example nor the overall article, but instead to minimally just make the current live sample work as expected for users.
items.title: Un-break the “Notify me!” live sample in “Using the Notifications API”

items.title: Extend Web/CSS/Class_selectors

items.content_html:
Summary

This wraps children of MathML <mtd> cells into an <mrow> group, except for the mtable and mtd articles:

find files/ -type f -name '*.md' | grep -v mtable/index.md | grep -v mtd/index.md | xargs sed -i 's|<mtd>|<mtd><mrow>|g;s|</mtd>|</mrow></mtd>|g'

Per the MathML specifications, there should be no rendering change. However Firefox does perform line breaking inside MathML table cells when the explicit <mrow> is absent (and does not otherwise). Note that this change is really only useful when the <mtd> element contains at least two children, but it's easier to write a command line if the remaining cases are included too.

Motivation

Users reported broken rendering in Firefox on twitter. Adding an explicit <mrow> prevents undesired line breaking inside MathML table cells.

Supporting details

twitter thread where the issue was reported
fix for the missing parentheses

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Wrap children of <mtd> elements into an <mrow> to prevent line breaking.

items.content_html:
Summary

Fix the polyfill of Math.fround that does not rely on Float32Array.

Motivation

As shown here:
https://gist.github.com/shicks/7a97ec6b3f10212e60a89a7f6d2d097d?permalink_comment_id=4048135#gistcomment-4048135
the old polyfill was incorrect, because it was breaking ties upwards when rounding. The spec of fround requires to break ties to even instead.

The new polyfill correctly breaks ties to even, even at the critical points of transitioning from subnormal to normal forms, and from finite to infinity.

To perform ties-to-even, the code relies on the natural rounding that will happen when getting into the subnormal forms of (64-bit) numbers.

In addition, the new polyfill does not assume that Math.log will always return the best approximation. The spec of Math.log explicitly says that it may not return the best approximation.

Supporting details

  • The gist with the old polyfill, with the test cases that break, and the new implementation: https://gist.github.com/shicks/7a97ec6b3f10212e60a89a7f6d2d097d?permalink_comment_id=4048135#gistcomment-4048135
  • The new polyfill is the one used by Scala.js. In the Scala.js codebase, it is written as a JS AST here. Its tests are here

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Fix the polyfill of Math.fround.
